revision.text:
==GS actions== Hello Neil. I cleaned up recent changes a bit today, there were lots of spammers in action. I saw fit to operate, despite the fact that there are enough sysops active. I shouldn't have done that perhaps. Could you let me know if GSs are welcome here? Or maybe, do you prefer to delete/block spams by yourselves? Thanks! (Good luck for your election) ;) --[[User:Frigotoni|'''Frigotoni''']][[:meta:User_talk:Frigotoni| ...'''i'm here''']]; 13:06, 3 February 2013 (UTC) :Hello there. Global sysops are welcome to block and delete obvious spam and vandalism here. There are only four really active local administrators and we have some coverage gaps (like this morning when I, who normally cover the UK morning hours, was out at a karate seminar..!). Thanks for your good wishes, [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 14:32, 3 February 2013 (UTC) == Ooops == Sorry but I deleted that "Guide to HSN" thing. It seemed to be advertising a shopping website and the user name seemed a give away - apologies if wrong. --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 09:35, 5 February 2013 (UTC) :They can complain if they don't like it... Thanks [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 09:51, 5 February 2013 (UTC) == Re:Wikivoyage == Thanks very much for updating the template. I think the links may have some relevance here, especially from books about cities and countries. After things quieten down on Wikivoyage, we will have a discussion about possible collaboration with sister sites, and I think it may be worth linking to Wikibooks' language guides for travellers to practice before going overseas. I'm sure the future is exciting for both projects! Thanks again, [[User:JamesA|JamesA]] ([[User talk:JamesA|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/JamesA|contribs]]) 05:06, 8 February 2013 (UTC) :We may well have some content that is better suited to Wikivoyage - like [[Enjoy Tokyo]] [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 08:58, 8 February 2013 (UTC) == About http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook == Hello, I have a question about http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook... can the recipes be imported from http://recipes . wikia . com/ ? That site has over 40.000 recipes [[User:GianoM|GianoM]] ([[User talk:GianoM|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GianoM|contribs]]) 10:38, 18 February 2013 (UTC) :Only if the license is compatible, and if the conditions of the license are met (e.g., by proper attribution). There is no automatic import tool available however. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 20:08, 18 February 2013 (UTC) == Java Programming book cleanup == Hi, During two years, I have worked on the [[Java Programming]] book and I think it's time to clean all the unused (I have checked it) redirects in the book: * [[Java Programming/Understanding a Java Program/Javadoc and other comments]] * [[Java Programming/Types/Numeric Types]] * [[Java Programming/Types]] * [[Java Programming/Swing Large Examples]] * [[Java Programming/Responsive Swing Application]] * [[Java Programming/Object-Oriented Programming Basics]] * [[Java Programming/Flow control/Conditional statements]] * [[Java Programming/First Examples]] * [[Java Programming/Beginning Java]] * [[Java Programming/Basic IO/Introduction to Streams]] * [[Java Programming/Basic Arithmetic/RandomNumbers]] * [[Java Programming/Types/Textual Primitives]] * [[Java Programming/Types/Numeric Primitives]] * [[Java Programming/Threads]] * [[Java Programming/SwingLayouts]] * [[Java Programming/Spring Framework]] * [[Java Programming/Random]] * [[Java Programming/IntroToStreams&Outputting Text]] * [[Java Programming/FirstExamples]] * [[Java Programming/Exceptions/NullPointerException]] * [[Java Programming/Design patterns]] * [[Java Programming/Basic Arithmetic/Math functions]] * [[Java Programming/BasicIO]] * [[Java Programming/Applets/MouseListener]] * [[Java Programming/Types/Boolean and Null Primitives]] * [[Java Programming/Swing Layouts]] * [[Java Programming/SwingLargeExamples]] * [[Java Programming/Reading Text Input]] * [[Java Programming/Object-Oriented Programming Basics/What is an Object?]] * [[Java Programming/How to use this book]] * [[Java Programming/Getting Started/Compilation]] * [[Java Programming/Flow control/Loops]] * [[Java Programming/First Java Program]] * [[Java Programming/Files and Streams]] * [[Java Programming/Conditional statements]] * [[Java Programming/Basic Arithmetic/Random Numbers]] * [[Java Programming/Basic Arithmetic/Large numbers]] * [[Java Programming/Applets/MouseListener]] [[User:Ftiercel|Ftiercel]] ([[User talk:Ftiercel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ftiercel|contribs]]) 19:53, 19 February 2013 (UTC) == Just wondering == if you'd noted [[WB:RR/G#Turning off Reader Feedback]]. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 12:05, 21 February 2013 (UTC) :I read it. Reader feedback is useful if it helps guide contributors on what to do to improve books. I suspect the tools we have, and those we are offered, won't do this. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 23:43, 21 February 2013 (UTC) == [[Template:Slideshow]] == Yesterday, I noticed you had imported this template. I imported some JS and CSS that it depends on to work. Not sure if you had planned to use it or were attempting to fulfill someone else's request. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 13:48, 16 March 2013 (UTC) :I think, and it was more than a year ago, that I imported it then history merged... but I can't remember! I certainly didn't import it for my use... [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 19:58, 16 March 2013 (UTC) == Deleting of Wikibook == I am new to Wikibooks. I had to create a Wikibooks for a University of Florida nutrition course assignment. This had to be graded first, then would be ultimately submitted to Wikibooks. Apparently, I typed the "wrong" comment in my description box, because my page was deleted by you before I could explain this. I put hours of work into my page and feel it was very rude of you to delete my hard work without allowing me to explain myself adequately. This project has a deadline, which now, I may not be able to meet due to the deletion of my work. Please explain who makes these decisions without giving the submitter a chance to give proper explanation first? I feel this action was completely inexcusable. [[User:Lcareynolds|Lcareynolds]] ([[User talk:Lcareynolds|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Lcareynolds|contribs]]) 01:01, 24 March 2013 (UTC) : I've tentatively undeleted the page in question; hopefully you two good folks can sort things out from there. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 03:04, 24 March 2013 (UTC) ::The community makes the rules, the administrators apply them. In this case there is a rule that Wikibooks is not to be used to host personal material and it can be deleted without discussion. Ergo I deleted it. If you are now saying it is intended to form part of a book, then it can be undeleted. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 08:23, 24 March 2013 (UTC) ::: In those grounds I disagree with the deletion (did you really deleted because of it ? or did you simply intended to pass another point ?). It had merit on the simple comment Lcareynolds provided (and he indicates it, and so by default his definition of "inexcusable" had no ground). ::: The comment seemed to indicate an unwillingness to license the work to Wikibooks, something that was automatic by the fact it was posted. ::: Then there is a valid issue of up to what point does the user own his creative work done for the University of Florida (it seems to depend from institution to institution). ::: Now personal space by definition makes anything on a personal space... well... personal material... (So please do not delete personal user space items on those grounds. Spam, offensive material and nonsense can be quickly delete but the rest may require a bit more work, even detailed personal info, about self, may require a quick deletion but will also force a request if the intention was to make it public). ::: Lcareynolds, you are new here but you could exert a bit more diplomacy, especially due to that fact. The page deletion only lasted for ~2hours there is no need exacerbate the issue, unless anyone opposed the restoration... ::: There was a dialog some time ago about restricting the use of the main userpage. I do not remember anyone opposing that view but there are however other users making use of it for other purposes. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 08:55, 24 March 2013 (UTC) ::::I read the edit summary to be an explicit statement that the content was not intended to be part of Wikibooks (which is why I reviewed in the first place) and when I read the content it looked very much like someone using Wikibooks to hold their personal homework. Most administrators (and not just on Wikibooks) delete this content as falling foul of the "not a web host" criterion. As you probably know Wikibooks is only lightly administered which is why we have a lot of inappropriate content in the user space, including copyright violations which remain awaiting administration for months. Therefor if I spot something I will typically deal with it immediately rather than leave it and risk it becoming a long term or bigger problem. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 09:43, 24 March 2013 (UTC) ::::: I continue to see an issue with your interpretation of «falling foul of the "not a web host" criterion» on userspace, in regards to other type of content beyond the exceptions we have on the deletion policy and have agreed upon (I think I covered those exceptions above, even dealing with private information has lead to mistakes). ::::: I'm not disagreeing with the need to provide stronger guidelines to the main user space or even stating that your view point is not practical to avoid abuse in consideration to the points you raise. Any experienced Wikibookian will not see a deletion as unredeemed action but it can alienate new users or even due to the personal implementation you are fallowing lead to loss o otherwise reusable content. Looking at the content on this deletion at direct examination without the other issues, that I agree justified the action, the content had some reusable value (has as the user will utilize it as soon as it gets "validation"). ::::: I had seen the initial post of this thread and found the sense of offense expressed to be exaggerated but only felt a need to interject due to the fact that I don't think we can apply "not a web host" with any consistency on the userspace. Part of my own userspace (and many other Wikibookians) could be deleted depending on how the acting administrator classified it, as I said personal space will consist in personal content there is no way to bypass that. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 10:42, 24 March 2013 (UTC) ::::: The more permissive we are within our rules about content the more attractive the project becomes to a vaster group of people, even contrarians. Even deletion of content from talk pages that one classifies as not important to the development of the book may be problematic especially if it relates to the subject (not opposing it just to demonstrate the correlation, since we are on your talk page). Personal decisions are at times necessary but should the exception as they otherwise tend to do more harm than good (this is valid to many other topics, like the repeated discussions regarding reviewers). ::::: I would again extend my support for at least a guideline establishing the proper use of the main user page. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 10:48, 24 March 2013 (UTC) (It seems we already have a [[Wikibooks:User pages|draft]] going on that front.) --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 10:54, 24 March 2013 (UTC) {{outdent|::::}} There are only two issues here, neither of which warrants a lot of controversy. First, this was a quite straightforwardly justified deletion. Webhosting. There is no ambiguous situation here that requires additional bureaucratic rules to cover it; webhosting is not allowed. The edit summary explicitly (though misleadingly, but that's the second issue) said it wasn't material meant to be released on Wikibooks. Second, it appears that the edit summary was misworded, the intent being to say that it ''would'' be used on Wikibooks. If admins weren't stretched so horribly thinly around here, it would have been perfectly reasonable to leave a note of inquiry on the user's talk page and give them some time to respond. I'd oppose red tape requiring such; it's counter-productive to choose competent admins and then fetter them. But the reason that didn't happen here was that it seemed straightforward ''and we don't have tools to help keep track of such cases''. It's worth taking a moment to contemplate what sort of general tool would make it easier to deal with such cases — keeping in mind that any tool implies some sort of extra work somewhere to use and maintain the tool, so it should be terrifically easy-and-natural to use and save a significant amount of work in order to be a net improvement. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 11:51, 24 March 2013 (UTC) : Pi zero explains it the right way. This page shouldn't really be used for an in-depth discussion of Wikibooks policy (unless the user initiates it). The edit summary gave clear justification for deletion so nothing was even remotely wrong about QuiteUnusual's decision. And, at the end of the day, anything deleted can be quickly restored if necessary.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 11:56, 24 March 2013 (UTC) :: I agree that the material was justifiably deleted under the circumstances. I would have done the same. That the material was restored almost immediately shows that our system is working as intended. The user was able to protest, and another admin was able to act. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jomegat|contribs]]) 12:35, 24 March 2013 (UTC) == hi == Thanks for the settings. :) [[User:Kayau|Kayau]] ([[User talk:Kayau|talk]] · [[Special:Contributions/Kayau|contribs]]) 23:58, 24 March 2013 (UTC) == Thank you QU == Thank you for helping me on editing. I am a beginner here, so I appreciate the help a lot. You must be a good father ;) [User:ShuBraque|ShuBraque]] ([[User talk:ShuBraque|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ShuBraque|contribs]]) 19:28, 28 March 2013 (UTC)
Thank you a lot for choosing me as a reviewer ^^ I appreciate you so much. [[User:ShuBraque|ShuBraque]] ([[User talk:ShuBraque|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ShuBraque|contribs]]) 17:09, 18 April 2013 (UTC) == Thank you QU == Thank you for helping me. Please let me know if I need to do any other changes. --[[User:Rudolpho|Rudolpho]] ([[User talk:Rudolpho|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Rudolpho|contribs]]) 18:45, 12 April 2013 (UTC) == Proposal to implement metadata on Wikibooks== Hi Neil, I wanted to give you an update on the previously discussed implementation of LRMI metatags on Wikibooks. There is no longer the need to use the html tag extension as was discussed in the previous proposal, because it is now supported by core mediawiki. In addition, these changes sanction all mediawiki installations by default and increase the assurance of LRMI as a long-term standard. If you're not familiar with [http://schema.org/CreativeWork Schema.org], it is a shared collection of standard schemas that was developed by Google, Bing, Yahoo, and Yandex to allow webmasters to markup their pages in ways recognized by major search providers. [http://wikisource-dev.wmflabs.org/w/index.php/CreativeWork This] page demonstrates these features in the context of wikisource and can demonstrate the optimization within a Google search engine [http://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/richsnippets?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwikisource-dev.wmflabs.org%2Fw%2Findex.php%2FMicrodata here]. With this said, let me know if you think it would be worthwhile to implement these metatags now that it will be done via Schema.org, or if you have further questions. [[User:Maximilian.Klein.LRMI|Maximilian.Klein.LRMI]] ([[User talk:Maximilian.Klein.LRMI|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Maximilian.Klein.LRMI|contribs]]) 05:15, 24 April 2013 (UTC) == Thank you QU == After starting my first WikiBook project ([[ElementarySpanish]]) I noticed a number of "(adding bookcat using AWB)" revisions from you. Looking into it helped me to understand how to use the book category tag for future pages and led me to the #wikibooks freenode channel, which I had not previously know about. Thanks for the assist! [[User:Billinghurst|Billinghurst]] ([[User talk:Billinghurst|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Billinghurst|contribs]]) 03:40, 22 May 2013 (UTC) == HSC Information Processes and Technology - Automated Manuafacturing == Quiteunusual, I feel you have been overly quick to delete the second posting of the Automated Manufacturing Page on Wikibooks. It was referenced with the link to the Board of Studies Site in the same way that the parent pages are referenced and there was only one section copied directly from the Board of Studies site which was clearly labelled as having been so copied. This section relates to Course outcomes and cannot be changed and must be referenced in order to give a learning context to the course. I understand that you are trying to keep the wikibooks site clear of copyright infringements but I am within the terms of use of the Board of Studies in that I am a teacher in NSW creating this page "for the purposes of bona fide research and study" (See the reference from the Board of Studies site below) The Introduction to the course was my own work and although covers some similar content to that of the board of studies I think that should be understandable as it is a book based upon a documented course outlined by the Board. Can you please give further details as to why you have removed the page after the concerns you cited after the first removal were remedied. I have a class of students (and a greater body of students in the wider state) who do not have access to a current textbook covering this content and it is my intention to build one collaboratively to prepare them for their Higher School Certificate. I will follow any reference conventions you impose in order to get this content through your stringent quality control system. I have no intention to steal ideas or in other ways infringe on the right to copy of any author but I feel this page in its second posting was within the law. --Source: the nsw board of studies website-- "School students in NSW and teachers in schools in NSW may copy reasonable portions of the material for the purposes of bona fide research or study. When you access the Material you agree: to use the Material for information purposes only to reproduce a single copy for personal bona fide study use only and not to reproduce any major extract or the entire Material without the prior permission of the Board of Studies NSW to acknowledge that the Material is provided by the Board of Studies NSW to include this copyright notice in any copy made not to modify the Material or any part of the Material without the express prior written permission of the Board of Studies NSW." This is out of process - you need to either tag the page for speedy deletion or raise it at [[WB:RFD|requests for deletion]]. The original author, or other contributors, may not agree with you removing their contributions. [[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 22:41, 22 June 2013 (UTC) :: If the original author won't agree with my blanking, he can revert it. If by process you mean [[WB:RFD]], that seems rather broken. Pages sit there for months with no action. In any case, the original author cannot restore a page that was fully deleted, while he can restore a blanked page. So a soft-deleting via blanking actually seems a good unbureaucratic thing. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Dan Polansky|contribs]]) 23:29, 22 June 2013 (UTC) :::I, and anyone else, can revert it if we don't agree - it doesn't need to be the original author. The point is '''you''' are not the original author so cannot unilaterally delete the content without some reasonable action. For example, you could ask for consensus from the authors by tagging it for speedy deletion or requesting a merge, move the content elsewhere and redirect the page or put it up for deletion. Leaving blank pages is just daft - an empty page that will confuse anyone who finds it as to its purpose. [[User:Ftiercel|Ftiercel]] ([[User talk:Ftiercel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ftiercel|contribs]]) 16:51, 4 August 2013 (UTC) == Review of contributions is causing duplication of work == Hi, I am working with college students to develop a wikibook "Biological Physics". We've noticed that our edits do not appear until they have been reviewed. They are often working independently to make contributions. I then intend to check their contributions periodically and give them feedback on their work. The review process on wikibooks seemingly causes duplication of work because students cannot instantly see and add to/edit what their peers have contributed. I understand the review is to avoid spamming and other issues, but is there a way to have our contributions posted instantly so that we aren't doing the same work multiple times? Thanks for your help, Troy [[User:Troycmessina|Troycmessina]] ([[User talk:Troycmessina|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Troycmessina|contribs]]) 13:52, 10 September 2013 (UTC) :For a logged in user the default is for them to see all edits - reviewed and unreviewed - whether they are reading or editing the page. The problem you are describing will only happen if they are logged out. As all your students presumably have accounts, the easiest way to avoid the problem is to ask them to ensure they are logged in. The reviewing system doesn't allow specific books to have auto-reviewed edits in the way you describe, sorry - [[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 13:58, 10 September 2013 (UTC) == Development Stages == Hi, I have asked [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Proposals#‎Development Stages|there]] to change the colors of the development ([[File:00%.svg]] [[File:25%.svg]] [[File:50%.svg]] [[File:75%.svg]] [[File:100%.svg]]) stages to more suitable ones. [[User:Meev0|Meev0]] ([[User talk:Meev0|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Meev0|contribs]]) 19:10, 4 February 2014 (UTC) :Nothing to worry about it. An anonymous user operating a "bot" (an automated or semi automated script) was spamming by creating various user pages. Anyone can create a user page - even somebody else's - and the abuse filters are less restrictive for these compared to main space pages, hence they are a target for spam. It doesn't mean your account was compromised. I'm not used to the Wiki-format, I hope I didn't write anywhere inappropriate. //Otto == request to undelete Cookbook:Anzac_biscuit (invalid copyright) == Is not a copyrighted recipe, the link you provided even implies this, as everyone and anyone can bake these biscuits, the oldest occurrence of the recipe dates back 1923 http://www.allysongofton.co.nz/index.php/page/articles/pi_articleid/57 pretty sure this puts it public domain by default, and this raises other questions, can you even copyright food? most sources I can find say no you cannot. :You may not be able to copyright food, but that isn't relevant as you can certainly copyright a recipe. The recipe in question was copied directly from a website, that website carries no notice saying it is in the public domain therefore it is considered to be copyright unless proven otherwise. The absence of a copyright notice isn't relevant - copyright exists whether it is "claimed" or not. To substantiate a claim that a specific recipe is in the public domain you would need to provide a source that contains the recipe that is in the public domain. Absent this, the precautionary principle applies and copyright is assumed. Of course, you could simply create your own recipe. The specific issue is the copy and paste that occurred. Look at your Special:Contributions ([[Special:MyContributions]]). Let's say the most recent edit there is timestamped {{nowrap|05:24, 16 May 2014}}; call that "one". Now skip over all the edits on the list that were no more than 48 hours before that (i.e., everything since {{nowrap|05:24, 14 May 2014}}). The next edit back is stamped {{nowrap|18:07, 11 May 2014}} (because there were two edits on {{nowrap|14 May}} but they were later than 05:24). That's "two". Skip over all edits no more than 48 hours before that (i.e., since {{nowrap|18:07, 9 May 2014}}). The next one back is {{nowrap|13:50, 5 May 2014}}; that's "three". And so on. :: Btw, if you make one edit after about 10:00 today UTC (i.e., anytime from now on), then one of your edits on {{nowrap|14 May}} is more than 48 hours before that, and you've got, I believe, six instead of five. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 10:48, 16 May 2014 (UTC) :Hmm. I don't think there is a major problem with having IP sandboxes any more than there's a problem with registered users having sandboxes, however, I see an IP sandbox as being temporary and deletable when it has been unused for a while rather than persistent until the registered editor requests deletion. [[User:Adikhajuria|Adikhajuria]] ([[User talk:Adikhajuria|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Adikhajuria|contribs]]) 09:08, 19 June 2014 (UTC) == About writing a Wikibook on Tor hidden services: Question about self-published *primary* sources (normally unreliable but Tor is an exception), and using *private* (not public) proxies to access Wikimedia == Hi, You checked and approved my edits to the Wikibook [[Guide to Tor hidden services and elements of the Tor network]] (which I originally created a few months ago and haven't worked on since), which I quite appreciate. I can't write this book all by myself, and am mainly trying to compose a good stub: filled with guidelines for future authors, as well as editorial precedents on Wikibooks and Wikipedia which could guide the creation of this article. I don't want to be making up rules as I go along but: * I suggested that all future authors use purple font (yes, they have to know some basic HTML) when making editorial comments (normally these would belong on the Discussion page, but sometimes they belong right next to the text they refer to, on the main page). * I tried to do this in order to allow editors and fellow authors to comment on parts of the book that are under construction or that might be controversial. * Please tell me whether using HTML purple font to label these comments, is OK under Wikibooks guidelines. If not, I can find another way to discuss changes with other editors (i.e. the Discussion page) but sometimes this seems more convenient. '''In my opinion a guide to Tor hidden services and the Tor network''' is greatly needed---but it digresses (transgresses?) into a grey area where things are not fully covered by Wikibooks guidelines as to what sources are reliable/verifiable/notable--- this same issue caused my edits to get deleted from Wikipedia (an action I accept in practice but still dispute in theory). '''If you know anything about Tor, you know that there is almost *no such thing* as a "reliable" secondary or tertiary source.''' This is why I accept Wikipedia's deletion of my edits and have moved the content to Wikibooks where I hope it will be accepted that I am making the best effort to keep my content reliable (and provide ample proof and first-hand evidence of its reliability). '''''However, it seems some editors on Wikipedia would rather accept unsourced content''''' than admit that the sources had to be on the Tor network itself. Basically, what I tried to do was to add Tor hidden services as sources about themselves on [[Wikipedia:List of Tor hidden services]], and cite their .onion addresses in the References list. This was in good faith. I understand why these edits were rejected '''but don't understand how they can reject my edits without having to delete the entire article because without "my" sources that I added, almost *all* of the material is unsourced'''. As I can firmly and easily establish (ask me for references), secondary sources, even media that's considered "reliable", is often inaccurate about Tor. Another thing I did was to '''use my own website as a source about itself''', since at the time I ran a Tor website which aimed to be a reliable directory of Tor hidden sites. (I no longer run it at this time and have removed or crossed out links to it.) '''Why I can justify this was,''' using primary sources '''''as sources about themselves''''' seems to be expressly permitted by Wikipedia (and Wikibooks) guidelines. '''I was making *no* claim''' that my website was a reliable/verifiable/notable source about '''anything but itself'''---but I tried to make the point that '''neither is any other site on Tor''', even so-called secondary sources (The New York Times failed to publish the current address of Silk Road, for instance, in an article on Tor; they instead published an address that was months outdated). '''My actions were "in good faith":''' because I made an earnest effort to ensure that all the content on my site was as reliable as any other source, and expressly noted in the article discussion pages (in a way that could be substantiated with proof) that the other sources cited were no more reliable (including the ones that passed the "notability" and "verifiablity" tests). So I have to ask you the following two questions before I write any further: # Can I use my own website as a source, (a) about itself, and (b) about other sites, if it can substantiate its own claims (i.e. if my site says a link works, you can click the link yourself and verify that it works, thus making it a verifiable primary source?) # '''IMPORTANT QUESTION:''' Is it '''OK to use a proxy to access Wikipedia (and Wikibooks)?''' ## We're talking about a '''*private* proxy"''', as opposed to an '''*open* proxy''' (which are already banned and blacklisted by Wikimedia). '''But *private* proxies are not banned, to my knowledge.''' Please correct me if this is wrong. ## I am '''NOT using a proxy to spam/vandalize,''' as you can see from my account and IP edit history; neither have been blacklisted, nor is there any reason to. ## I want to use a proxy to edit Wikibooks '''because I do business on Tor anonymously, and host websites anonymously, and sharing what I know about Tor could be (at worst) incriminating and (at best) reveal things about my anonymous activities that I don't want to be traced back to my identity'''. I '''PRIVATELY LEASE the IP I am connecting from''', it is NOT shared by anyone else, and WILL NOT be used to spam/vandalize as long as I am in control of it. '''Please tell me if this is OK.''' ## I know Wikimedia bans editing from Tor, but this is totally different. Although I connect to the internet through Tor, it is rerouted through this unique IP that I privately lease. And therefore no spam will come from my IP address. '''PayPal, for instance, bans proxies/VPNs altogether''' but this is because it's illegal to conduct financial operations under an assumed identity. This case is totally different: I just want to write books as an anonymous author. # '''If you tell me this is NOT OK,''' I can just go to a public library to edit Wikibooks anonymously although this is less convenient than a private proxy. '''I don't have to use a proxy,''' but I don't want to use my home computer directly to make these edits. --[[User:ContingentConsciousness|ContingentConsciousness]] ([[User talk:ContingentConsciousness|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ContingentConsciousness|contribs]]) 09:11, 8 July 2014 (UTC) :Font colour - not a problem. Reliable sourcing is not considered a major issue here unless the subject is contentious (e.g., if it was negative material about a living person). You should have no problem using your website as a "reference" (let's call it an "example"). Wikimedia bans editing from Tor but it shouldn't cause you a problem editing from your registered account unless a global block is in place that prevents registered users editing. If this does impact you, we can flag your account as IP Block Exempt here. [[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 09:43, 8 July 2014 (UTC) == Well I'd love it if you'd make me exempt from IP blocks == I say this because currently I'm paying for a (private) proxy (as I mentioned above) --- basically paying so that I can connect through Tor and then reroute my connection through a proxy that isn't blacklisted by Wikimedia. I understand why this is necessary (and necessarily to comply with Wikimedia's "No Open Proxies" policy) because connecting through this IP address proves I'm me as opposed to a spammer/vandal. Still, this isn't necessary, because when I log in with my username/password it proves I'm me (and am responsible for my edits) as opposed to a spammer/vandal. While people who use Tor or open proxies may want to vandalize and should be blocked in general, when a Tor/open proxy connects through my account, it will always be me. So I would love to be placed on the whitelist. Thank you if you can do this: from Wikimedia policy [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia:Open proxies]], :::''"for example, editors in countries where Wikipedia is censored, such as China, should sign up for free access to Wikipedia-only proxies at Wikipedia:WikiProject on closed proxies or read Wikipedia:Advice to users using Tor to bypass the Great Firewall. Additionally, because of the creation of the IP block exemption flag, '''editors,''' like those in China, '''who have a demonstrated need to use proxies or Tor to edit may be given the ability to edit from blocked IPs.''' There ''are'' things I would be able to say about Tor in Wikibooks that I wouldn't be willing to say if it could be traced to me, so this helps. '''Oh, one other reason.''' I am considering running a '''Tor exit relay''' from my home internet connection. If I do this, I will be blocked from editing Wikipedia/Wikibooks even from my house unless my account is exempt from IP blocks. '''Thanks if you can help me.''' --[[User:ContingentConsciousness|ContingentConsciousness]] ([[User talk:ContingentConsciousness|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ContingentConsciousness|contribs]]) 19:22, 8 July 2014 (UTC) :I've flagged your account as IP Block Exempt here at Wikibooks. The exemption only affects Wikibooks - if you want to edit other projects you'll need to request an exemption there too. [[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 07:51, 9 July 2014 (UTC) == Groups of vandal IPs == I've been noticing, just lately, groups of similar IPs collaborating to do whole batteries of vandalism edits to a page. (Fortunately, rejecting the edits on a sighted page removes it all in one stroke even though rollback wouldn't.) Have you observed this vandalism technique? (Is it something that's been going on for ages and I've only just noticed?) --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 16:37, 11 July 2014 (UTC) ::I hadn't noticed it getting worse but then that doesn't mean it isn't. I have had a few instances recently where the IPs have been a school owned range so via OTRS I've reported it and asked them to investigate. I'll keep an eye out [[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 16:50, 11 July 2014 (UTC) == An important message about renaming users ==
Dear QuiteUnusual, I am cross-posting this message to many places to make sure everyone who is a Wikimedia Foundation project bureaucrat receives a copy. If you are a bureaucrat on more than one wiki, you will receive this message on each wiki where you are a bureaucrat. As you may have seen, work to perform the Wikimedia cluster-wide [[mw:SUL finalisation|single-user login finalisation]] (SUL finalisation) is taking place. This may potentially effect your work as a local bureaucrat, so please read this message carefully. Why is this happening? As currently stated at [[m:Global rename policy|the global rename policy]], a global account is a name linked to a single user across all Wikimedia wikis, with local accounts unified into a global collection. Previously, the only way to rename a unified user was to individually rename every local account. This was an extremely difficult and time-consuming task, both for stewards and for the users who had to initiate discussions with local bureaucrats (who perform local renames to date) on every wiki with available bureaucrats. The process took a very long time, since it's difficult to coordinate crosswiki renames among the projects and bureaucrats involved in individual projects. The SUL finalisation will be taking place in stages, and one of the first stages will be to turn off Special:RenameUser locally. This needs to be done as soon as possible, on advice and input from Stewards and engineers for the project, so that no more accounts that are unified globally are broken by a local rename to usurp the global account name. Once this is done, the process of global name unification can begin. The date that has been chosen to turn off local renaming and shift over to entirely global renaming is 15 September 2014, or three weeks time from now. In place of local renames is a new tool, hosted on Meta, that allows for global renames on all wikis where the name is not registered will be deployed. Your help is greatly needed during this process and going forward in the future if, as a bureaucrat, renaming users is something that you do or have an interest in participating in. The Wikimedia Stewards have set up, and are in charge of, a new community usergroup on Meta in order to share knowledge and work together on renaming accounts globally, called [[m:Global renamers|Global renamers]]. Stewards are in the process of creating documentation to help global renamers to get used to and learn more about global accounts and tools and Meta in general as well as the application format. As transparency is a valuable thing in our movement, the Stewards would like to have at least a brief public application period. If you are an experienced renamer as a local bureaucrat, the process of becoming a part of this group could take as little as 24 hours to complete. You, as a bureaucrat, should be able to apply for the global renamer right on Meta by the [[m:SRGP|requests for global permissions]] page on 1 September, a week from now. In the meantime please update your local page where users request renames to reflect this move to global renaming, and if there is a rename request and the user has edited more than one wiki with the name, please send them to [[:m:SRUC|the request page for a global rename]]. Stewards greatly appreciate the trust local communities have in you and want to make this transition as easy as possible so that the two groups can start working together to ensure everyone has a unique login identity across Wikimedia projects. Completing this project will allow for long-desired universal tools like a global watchlist, global notifications and many, many more features to make work easier. If you have any questions, comments or concerns about the SUL finalisation, read over the [[m:SUL|Help:Unified login]] page on Meta and leave a note on the talk page there, or on the talk page for [[m:Talk:Global renamers|global renamers]]. You can also contact me on [[m:User talk:Keegan (WMF)|my talk page on meta]] if you would like. I'm working as a bridge between Wikimedia Foundation Engineering and Product Development, Wikimedia Stewards, and you to assure that SUL finalisation goes as smoothly as possible; this is a community-driven process and I encourage you to work with the Stewards for our communities. Thank you for your time. -- [[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan (WMF)]] [[m:User talk:Keegan (WMF)|talk]] 18:24, 25 August 2014 (UTC) --This message was sent using [[m:MassMessage|MassMessage]]. Was there an error? [[m:Talk:MassMessage|Report it!]]

page.title: Recipes for the Design of Experiments/Chapter 1: One Factor, Two Level Experiments

revision.text:
This is the collection of R recipes for the analysis of one factor, two level experiments. Each of these recipes are structured in the ''Setting, Design, Analysis'' paradigm and the ''Design'' portion is structured in four parts: ''Exploratory Analysis, Testing, Estimation and Model Adequacy Checking.'' Put your recipes here.
-> These data are a collection of various measures, including variables such as elevation, temperature (surface and air), ozone, air pressure, and cloud cover. For this section, a t-test was conducted to explore whether a statistically significant difference existed between the two temperature variables. The H0 was that no difference existed between the mean temperature values of both factors, whereas the HA was that a statistically significant difference existed between the two factors. Based on the results of the test, the H0 was rejected W.R.T. an alpha value of .05. However, after model adequacy checking was performed, the results were invalidated due to the fact that the t-test assumes normality, and the Shapiro-Wilks normality test confirmed that the data are not normal. Further steps to "coerce" the data to be normally distributed include performing data transformations, but this action has not yet been completed. http://rpubs.com/manzat/28671
-> The following is an analysis of a data set which includes a collection of wind speed, barometric pressure, longitude, latitude and time points for a large number of storms recorded by NASA. In my analysis I decided to examine if there was a significant statistical difference in the wind speed and pressure readings between hurricanes and extratropical storms. This analysis was performed through the use of a t-test and a QQ plot as a check for model adequacy. http://rpubs.com/adamato/28910
-> Using fuel economy data from the EPA collected from 1985-2015, a one-factor, two-level experiment is performed to see if the “make” of a vehicle has a statistically significant effect on the fuel economy of that vehicle. The two “makes” that are considered in this analysis include ‘Toyota’ and ‘Audi’. Additionally, this analysis separately considers two different metrics for measuring fuel economy, including both highway fuel economy [in mpg] (“hwy”) and city fuel economy [in mpg] (“cty”). Upon performing this analysis, it was determined that the fact that these two vehicles are classified by different “makes” likely does appear to have an effect on the average city fuel economy that is achieved when driving either “make” of vehicle. However, the fact that these two vehicles are classified by different “makes” does not appear to have an effect on the average highway fuel economy that is achieved when driving either “make” of vehicle. - Brendan Howell
http://rpubs.com/howelb/29127
-> The following analysis is conduced based on the EPA fuel economy data from 1985 to 2015. To explore the effect of vehicle engine power (number of cylinders) on fuel economy, a one factor (number of cylinders), two level (cyl = 4 and cyl = 6) experiment was carried out and a linear regression model is estimated to quantify the marginal effect. The result shows that the vehicle fuel economy decreases with the number of cylinders in the vehicle. http://rpubs.com/serena049/doehw1
-> The html file below utilizes fuel economy data that has been collect by the EPA from 1985 to 2015. Specific data is analyzed to conduct a one-factor, two-level experiment to determine if the variation in the make of a vehicle is responsible for the variation in highway gas mileage. The factor, "make," is grouped into two levels, "Toyota" and "Honda," with a response variable of "hwy" (the highway mileage). An unpaired, two-sample t-test, with a null hypothesis that the highway mileage means of both vehicle makes are equal, will be conducted. http://rpubs.com/maxwinkelman/28916
This analysis utilizes ‘nycflights13’ data set containing all information about flights that departed from NYC (JFK, EWR and LGA) in 2013. There are 336,776 flights in total. In order to study the underlying causes of flight delay an experiment was conducted which can be termed as ‘one factor- two level’ experiment. Here ‘time-delay’ is the factor and ‘departure time-delay’ and ‘arrival time-delay’ are two levels. We conduct a t-test to test the null hypothesis , ‘mean of the departure time delay is equal to the mean of the arrival time delay’. This is essentially to try and test whether there are other factors that contribute to the delay of an aircraft apart from the delay in its take-off time. For this purpose we take a sub-set of the data (only UA flights departing from JFK). Our t-test experiment leads to the rejection of the null hypothesis. However, our exploratory data analysis as well as diagnostic check leads us to the conclusion that the data is not normally distributed. Therefore the assumption based on which we conduct the t-test is flawed. This leads us to the conclusion that our t-test is not valid for our current data set. http://rpubs.com/Uzma_1004/28917
The following analysis is based on the data set called 'nasaweather' collected from National Hurricane Center. It takes the classification of different types of storms and their respective air pressure measurement to perform a t-test. As you will see in the analysis, the results show that we reject the null hpothesis that the means of Tropical Storms does not equal the means of Hurricanes. http://rpubs.com/hsiac/28942
The following analysis investigates if electric/hybrid cars are actually more fuel efficient than cars with more traditional gasoline engines. This analysis looked at both highway and city driving where the data was derived from an EPA fuel economy dataset from 1985 to 2015. Individual analyses of highway and city driving were conducted in a one-factor, two-level manner using t-tests. Cars with electric/hybrid engines were determined to get significantly better gas mileage than cars with traditional gasoline engines on the highway as well as around the city. http://rpubs.com/JohnMariani/28953
->The following link utilizes the R data "storms" from the "nasaweather" package. "Storms" includes 4 observations a day for every storm named from 1995 to 2000. The storm name, year, month, day, hour, latitude, longitude, pressure, wind speed, and type of storm were recorded for each observation. This analysis will focus on only two of the observations a day (hour 0 and 12) and one factor, two level testing to examine if the variation in wind could be explained by the hour of each day. Exploritory data analysis, a t-test, and normality testing is performed. There is also a section at the end that covers contingencies if the assumptions are broken. http://rpubs.com/svoboa/28937
The following analysis is based on the 'nycflights13' dataset which contains information of flights from NYC, including JFK, EWR and LGA. Also plane information and weather condition are recorded in this dataset. It is known to all that several airlines are usually not on time, and this analysis is in order to test effect of airlines on time delay and help passengers choose the best one. We take test for Delta Airline as an example, considering it as a 'one factor - two level' model, where 'departure delay' and 'arrival delay' are two levels. To block possible cofounding factros we only select flights from JFK. T-test shows there is no relationship between two factors, however, following tests reveal that data is not normally distributed, therefore it is not correct to conduct t-test in this case. This analysis is the first version, it is still needed to be improved in the future. http://rpubs.com/chenh16/29271 -> The following is an experiment designed to investigate the relationship between year and storm wind speed from the 'nasaweather' dataset. The experiment will look into the normality of the data and also attempt to discover whether or not there is a significant difference between of the means via two-sample t-test. http://rpubs.com/macchm/30638
->This experiment is testing to see if there are differences in the Mean Surface Temperature from Clear Sky Composite and Mean Near-Surface Air Temperature in the month of January. The Mean Surface Temperature from Clear Sky Composite is the monthly mean temperature based on the energy being emitted from the Earth’s surface under clear sky conditions in K. The Mean Near-Surface Air Temperature is the monthly mean temperature of the air near the surface of the Earth in K. http://rpubs.com/hsiac/30643 -by Cheryl Tran
-> The following link is an experiment that utilizes flight data from NYC, in particular date of flight, departure and arrival times, departure and arrival times, departure and arrival locations and some information about the plane. The experiment looks to examine the effects of the origin on the departure delay time. The assumption being that the a flight's delay is due to the problems in the departure airport. The study firsts looks to explore the data with summary statistics, box plots and histograms. The data is analyzed using t-tests and the normality of the data is also checked using QQ plots and the Shapiro-Wilk test. Lastly it addresses possible contingencies in the experiment. http://rpubs.com/Tothk2/31630 -By Kevin Toth
-> The following analysis examined flight data from planes leaving from three of New York City's major airports. The data includes factors such as the the date, the time of arrival/departure, the arrival/departure delays, the airline carrier, the origin and destination, along with multiple others. In particular, this experiment analyzed delays, and how they are related to the origin and departure city, along with the specific airline carrier responsible for the flights. A one factor, two level t-test was completed for two different airline carriers and two different origin locations. Unfortunately, after completing a Shapiro-Wilks test for normality, it was found that the data is nonparametric, and would therefore need additional testing using nonparametric methods. http://rpubs.com/braunj6/31855
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Welcome
revision.text:
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, A Michener!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
--[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 13:37, 15 September 2014 (UTC)

page.title: Learning Python 3 with the Linkbot/Linkbot Multitasking

revision.comment: Added misc section
revision.text: __TOC__ ==="Non-blocking" Linkbot Functions=== Lets take an inventory of all of the functions that we've used so far to control various aspects of the Linkbot. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Function Name !! Function Description |- | setLEDColor(r, g, b) || Changes the LED color based on red, green, and blue intensities. |- | setBuzzerFrequency(Hz) || Makes the Linkbot buzzer play a frequency in Hertz. |- | moveJoint(jointNum, degrees) || Makes a single motor move. |- | move(degrees, degrees, degrees) || Makes multiple motors move simultaneously |} Using these functions, we can move our robot around, change the robot's LED color, and make the robot beep or play simple melodies. However, using only these functions, it is not possible to make a robot play a tune and change its LED colors while the robot is moving. For example, lets say we want to make our robot beep 2 times _while_ our robot is moving. We can try something like this: {{Message box|heading = Note! | message= The examples in this section are presented without the necessary initializing code shown in previous chapters. To run these examples, you will need to include the following lines of code at the top of your program: import barobo dongle = barobo.Dongle() dongle.connect() myLinkbot = dongle.getLinkbot('ABCD') # Replace 'ABCD' with your Linkbot's ID }} myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) # 1 time.sleep(0.25) # 2 myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) # 3 time.sleep(0.25) # 4 myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.move(180, 0, -180) # 5 Lets reason our way through each major point of this program. # First, we turn on the buzzer on the Linkbot. It starts buzzing # Pause the program for 0.25 seconds # Turn off the Linkbot's buzzer. # Pause the program for another 0.25 seconds. The end result of steps 1-4 is that the Linkbot buzzes its buzzer for 0.25 seconds. The next four lines do the same exact thing. # At this point, the Linkbot has buzzed twice, and now the move() function makes the Linkbot roll forward. This is almost what we want to do, except we want the robot to beep twice while the robot is moving; not before it starts moving. Lets try again: myLinkbot.move(180, 0, -180) # 1 myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) # 2 time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) This program is almost exactly the same as the program before except we relocated the move() function to the beginning of the program. Will this program make the robot beep twice as the robot is moving? # First, we call the move() function which moves the robot's motors. The robot begins moving. However, the program stays at item 1 until the move() function is completed. After the robot finishes moving, the program continues. # Here, the robot turns the buzzer on similar to the previous example. Using setBuzzerFrequency() and time.sleep(), it makes the buzzer beep twice. ===The moveNB() Function=== As we can see, we have failed yet again to make the robot beep twice while moving. In order to make the robot do these things simultaneously, we must use a similar but new type of function: Non-blocking functions. Lets take a look at an example: myLinkbot.moveNB(180, 0, -180) # 1 myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) # 2 time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) # Here, instead of using the move() function, we use the moveNB() function. The "NB" in the function name stands for "non-blocking". Both functions move the motors on the Linkbot, but there is one important difference: The NB version of the function "returns" immediately. What this means is Python continues on to the next line of code immediately without waiting for the movement to finish first. In other words, the moveNB() function does not "block" Python from continuing on immediately after the function is called. # Now, the Linkbot begins playing its buzzer while the Linkbot is still moving. We've accomplished our task! This program will move the robot and beep twice while the robot is moving. ===The moveWait() Function=== Now lets try one more example. Lets say we want to make the robot move its wheels 180 degrees to roll forward while beeping twice, and then change the LED color to green after the movement is done. To accomplish this, we introduce the moveWait() function. Lets take a look and see how it works: myLinkbot.moveNB(180, 0, -180) # 1 myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) # 2 time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(0) time.sleep(0.25) myLinkbot.moveWait() # 3 myLinkbot.setLEDColor(0, 255, 0) # 4 # As before, this line tells the robot to begin moving motors 1 and 3. Since we used the "NB" version of the function, Python continues directly on to the next line of code even though the robot is still moving. # The next several lines of code beep the robot twice, similar to before. # Here, we call a function called moveWait(). This function blocks until all motor movements on the robot are finished. In effect, Python will wait at # 3 until the motors are done moving. # Here, we set the LED color to green. If we had omitted moveWait() at # 3, the LED color would've been set whether the motors were still moving or not. By using the moveWait() function, we force Python to wait for the motors to stop moving before setting the LED color. ===Other Non-Blocking Functions=== Almost all Linkbot movement commands have a non-blocking version with the "NB" suffix. The ones that do not have a non-blocking version are the ones that move a Linkbot's motor continuously forever. We haven't explored any of them yet, but they are out there. These functions do not have non-blocking versions because they would block forever. All of the functions that begin with the prefix "set", such as setBuzzerFrequency() and setLEDColor(), can be considered non-blocking because of how fast the buzzer and LED colors are set. For instance, if you run the following snippet of code: myLinkbot.setBuzzerFrequency(440) myLinkbot.setLEDColor(0, 255, 0) The Linkbot would appear to start buzzing and change the LED color to green simultaneously. Technically, the robot is actually doing one before the other, but the two things happen so fast (typically within 5 milliseconds of each other) that it is practically simultaneous. {{navigation |previous=Decisions |next=Debugging}} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Introduction to Numerical Methods/Roots of Equations

revision.comment: /* False-Position Method */
revision.text:
=Root Finding= Objectives: * find solutions of quadratic and cubic equations * derive the formula and follow the algorithms for the solutions of non-linear equations using the following methods: ** Bisection ** Newton-Raphson ** Secant ** False-Position
Resources * [http://mathforcollege.com/nm/#sthash.WAEKs9MN.dpbs book chapters on various methods] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root-finding_algorithm Root Finding Algorithms] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bisection_method Bisection Method] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_method Newton's Method] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secant_method Secant Method] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_position_method False-Position Method]
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_of_a_function Roots (or Zeros) of a function f(x)] are values of x that produces an output of 0. Roots can be real or complex numbers. Finding the root of <math>f(x)-g(x)</math> is the same as solving the equation <math>f(x) = g(x)</math>. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_solving Solving an equation] is finding the values that satisfy the condition specified by the equation.
Lower degree (quadratic, cubic, and quartic) polynomials have closed-form solutions, but numerical methods may be easier to use. To solve a quadratic equation we can use the quadratic formula:
:<math>ax^2+bx+c=0</math>
:<math>x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac\ }}{2a}</math>
There are many [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root-finding_algorithm root-find algorithms] for solving equations numerically.
==Bisection Method== The bisection method starts with two guesses and uses a binary search algorithm to improve the answers. If a function is continuous between the two initial guesses, the bisection method is guaranteed to converge. Here is a picture that illustrates the idea:
[[File:Bisection method.svg|400px|A few steps of the bisection method applied over the starting range [a1;b1]. The bigger red dot is the root of the function.]]
The advantages of bisection method include guaranteed convergence on continuous functions and the error is bounded.
The disadvantages of bisection method include relatively slow convergence and non convergence on certain functions.
<!-- <source lang="python"> def function(x): return x**3-x-2
# inputs: function f, endpoint values a, b, tolerance # maximum iterations nmax # output: value differs from a root of f(x)=0 by less # than tolerance def bisection(f, a, b, tolerance, nmax = 100): i = 1 while i <= nmax: c = (a+b)/2.0 if f(c) == 0 or (b-a)/2.0 < tolerance: print "solution is ", c break; if f(a)*f(c) > 0: # same sign a = c else: b = c i+=1 if i>nmax: print "method failed."
bisection(function, 1, 2, 0.0001, 20) </source> --> ==Newton-Raphson Method== [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_method Newton's Method] (a.k.a Newton-Raphson Method) is an open method for solving non-linear equations. Contrary to a bracketing-method (e.g. bisection method) Newton's method needs one initial guess but it doesn't guarantee to converge.
The basic idea of Newton's method is as follows: : Given a function ''f'' of "x" and a initial guess <math>x_{0}</math> for the root of this function, a better guess <math>x_{1}</math> is :<math>x_{1} = x_0 - \frac{f(x_0)}{f'(x_0)} </math> : This is the Newton-Raphson formula.
The following animation illustrates the method:
[[File:NewtonIteration Ani.gif|400px|The function ƒ is shown in blue and the tangent line is in red. We see that xn+1 is a better approximation than xn for the root x of the function f.]]
Lets solve the following equations using Newton's method: :<math>f(x)=x^{2}+2</math> :<math>f(x)=sin(x)=0</math> :<math>f(x)=a-\frac{1}{x}=0</math>
<source lang="python"> from sympy import Symbol, diff, sin x = Symbol('x') y = sin(x) derivative = diff(y, x)
''' Solve f with initial guess g using Newton's method. Stop when the absolute relative approximate error is smaller than the tolerance or the max # iterations is reached. ''' def newton(f, derivative, g, tolerance, max_iteration): x_previous = g for i in range(max_iteration): x_current = x_previous - \ y.subs(x, x_previous).evalf()/derivative.subs(x, x_previous).evalf()
error = abs((x_current-x_previous)/x_current) print "current x:", x_current, " error:", error
x_previous = x_current
if error < tolerance: break;
newton(y, derivative, 5, 0.005, 15) </source> <source lang="bash"> $ python newton.py current x: 8.38051500624659 error: 0.403377955140806 current x: 10.1008867567293 error: 0.170318883075941 current x: 9.29864101772707 error: 0.0862755898924158 current x: 9.42545121429349 error: 0.0134540186653470 current x: 9.42477796066766 error: 7.14344283379346e-5 </source>
===Limitations of Newton's Method=== ====Division by Zero==== Because a division is involved in Newton's formula when the denominator becomes zero the method won't continue correctly. The following program demonstrates this issue. <source lang="python"> from sympy import Symbol, diff x = Symbol('x') y = 4 - 1.0/x derivative = diff(y, x)
''' Solve f with initial guess g using Newton's method. Stop when the absolute relative approximate error is smaller than the tolerance or the max # iterations is reached. ''' def newton(f, derivative, g, tolerance, max_iteration): x_previous = g for i in range(max_iteration): x_current = x_previous - \ y.subs(x, x_previous)/derivative.subs(x, x_previous)
error = abs((x_current-x_previous)/x_current) print "current x:", x_current, " error:", error
x_previous = x_current
if error < tolerance: break;
newton(y, derivative, 0.5, 0.005, 15) </source> Output: <source lang="bash"> $ python newton.py current x: 0 error: oo current x: nan error: nan current x: nan error: nan current x: nan error: nan current x: nan error: nan current x: nan error: nan ... </source>
====Divergence at Inflection Points==== When the initial guess is near a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection_point inflection point] the method may diverge from the desired root.
The following code using the same implementation of Newton's method (assume the newton function is imported) demonstrates divergence at an inflection point (x=0). <source lang="bash"> from sympy import Symbol, diff x = Symbol('x') y = (x-1)**3 + 0.5
derivative = diff(y, x) newton(y, derivative, 5, 0.005, 15) </source> <source lang="bash"> $ python newton.py current x: 3.65625000000000 error: 0.367521367521368 current x: 2.74721164936563 error: 0.330894909696631 current x: 2.11021215705302 error: 0.301865141940137 current x: 1.60492272680972 error: 0.314837232847788 current x: 0.947823175470885 error: 0.693272298403532 current x: -60.2548036313237 error: 1.01573025084058 current x: -39.8365801731819 error: 0.512549605648313 current x: -26.2244867245776 error: 0.519060433539279 current x: -17.1498826852607 error: 0.529135050417335 current x: -11.1004277326071 error: 0.544974941360464 current x: -7.06809009701998 error: 0.570498901434099 current x: -4.38128712811798 error: 0.613245124168828 current x: -2.59328016409484 error: 0.689476975445585 current x: -1.40842833626215 error: 0.841258157995587 current x: -0.634351912031382 error: 1.22026340513730 </source>
==Secant Method== [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secant_method Secant method] is similar to Newton's method in that it is an open method and use a intersection to get the improved estimate of the root. Secant method avoids calculating the first derivatives by estimating the derivative values using the slope of a secant line.
The following figure illustrates the secant method with two initial guesses and two successive improved estimates: [[File:Secant method.svg|400px|The first two iterations of the secant method. The red curve shows the function f and the blue lines are the secants. For this particular case, the secant method will not converge.]]
The formula for secant method is as follows: :<math> x_{i+1} =x_{i}-\frac{f(x_{i})(x_{i}-x_{i-1})}{f(x_{i})-f(x_{i-1})} </math>
==False-Position Method== The false-position method is similar to the bisection method in that it requires two initial guesses (bracketing method). Instead of using the midpoint as the improved guess, the false-position method use the root of secant line that passes both end points. The following figure illustrates the idea. [[File:False position method.svg|400px|The first two iterations of the false position method. The red curve shows the function f and the blue lines are the secants.]]
The formula for false-position method is as follows: :<math>x_{r}=\frac{x_uf(x_l) - x_lf(x_u)}{f(x_l) - f(x_u)}</math>
