revision.text:
<big><big> '''Exercise for reducing the risk of stroke''' </big></big>
=== Background- What is a stroke? === A stroke is a brain attack which blocks off the blood flow that carries oxygen and nutrients to brain tissue<ref name ="National STROKE Association">National STROKE Association. (2013). <http://www.stroke.org/site/DocServer/STROKE_101_Fact_Sheet.pdf?docID=4541> [Accessed: 29/09/14].</ref>. When deprived of this blood supply two million brain cells die every minute, every moment increasing the risk of permanent brain damage, disability or death<ref name= "Mayo Clinic"> Mayo Clinic Staff. Mayo Clinic. (2014). <http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/stroke/basics/definition/con-20042884> [Accessed: 29/09/14]. </ref>.
==== What are the different types of stroke? ====
# Ischemic stroke – This is the most common type of stroke accounting for 87% of stokes suffered. Ischemic stroke occurs when a blood clot or fatty deposit (i.e. plaque, atheroma) block the arteries<ref name="National STROKE Association"/><ref name="Heart foundation"> Heart Foundation. (2014). <http://www.heartfoundation.org.au> [Accessed: 29/09/14].</ref>. # Hemorrhagic stroke – This is only responsible for 13% of all strokes, however, is more fatal accounting for 30% of all stroke deaths. Hemorrhagic strokes occur when a blood vessel in the brain bursts and leaks blood into the brain <ref name= "National STROKE Association"/><ref name= "Heart foundation"/>. This is typically as result of high blood pressure and/or diseases involving the blood vessels in your brain. # Transient ischemic attacks [TIA] – these are also known as ‘mini strokes’. These are a major precursor for strokes as 40% who suffer a TIA will go on to have a stroke<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/><ref name= "Heart foundation"/>. As you age, risk of suffering a TIA increases<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/>.
==== What are some risk factors for stroke?<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/><ref name= "Heart foundation"/> ==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Medical risk factors !! Lifestyle risk factors<ref>Shinton, R. Lifelong exposures and the potential for stroke prevention: the contribution of cigarette smoking, exercise, and body fat. Epidemiology and community health. 1997; 51:138-143.</ref> |- | Suffered a stroke before || Smoking |- | Suffered a TIA before || Being overweight |- | High cholesterol || Excess alcohol consumption |- | High blood pressure || High sodium diet |- | Heart disease || |- | Arterial fibrillation<ref name= "Gordan, N.F.">Gordan, N.F., Gulanick, M., et al. Physical activity and Exercise Recommendations for Stroke Survivors. American Heart Association. 2004; 35:1232-1234</ref> || |- | Carotid artery disease<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/> || |- |}
Strokes are not biased to age, sex, or race, and so everyone has a stroke risk<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/><ref name= "Heart foundation"/>. Some factors do increase an individual’s risk. Those over 55 years of age have an increased risk<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/>. Men when they are younger have a greater risk than women, but as women age they are more at risk, especially to fatality as result of stroke<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/>. African Americans have an increased stroke risk as do diabetics and those with a family history of stroke<ref name= "National STROKE Association"/>. But no matter the number of factors someone has, everyone should do what they can to minimise their risk factors.
=== What benefits will I see from exercise?<ref name= "Heart foundation"/><ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/> ===
Up to 80% of all strokes are avoidable. This is because most strokes occur as result of unhealthy lifestyle choices. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Exercise will increase your !! Exercise will decrease your |- | Chance of recovery || Blood sugar levels |- | General health || Blood cholesterol levels |- | Aerobic capacity || Blood pressure |- | Quality of life || Body weight (when accompanied by healthy eating)
|- | Coronary artery endothelial function || Risk of Heart disease |- |}
=== Recommendations for Exercise ===
Simply by meeting the daily recommended physical activity guidelines, stroke risk can be dramatically decreased<ref>Australian Government Department of Health. (2014). <http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/content/health-pubhlth-strateg-phys-act-guidelines> [Accessed: 29/09/14].</ref>. More specific exercise programs can be prescribed to cater for individual medications, disabilities, requirements and so forth.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Exercise Type !! Benefits !! How much |- | Vigorous aerobic exercise<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/> || * Improve peak oxygen uptake * Improve workload * lower blood pressure, and blood sugar * improve sensorimotor function * improve aerobic capacity || 3 times per week |- | Treadmill aerobic exercise<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/><ref>Macko, R.F., Desouza, C.A., et al. Treadmill Aerobic Exercise Training Reduces the Energy Expenditure and Cardiovascular Demands of Hemiparetic Gait in Chronic Stroke Patients. American Heart Association. 1997. 28: 326-330</ref> || * reduces submaximal energy expenditure * improved cardiovascular fitness * daily living tasks done at lower percentage of aerobic capacity * lower blood pressure, and blood sugar * lower cholesterol || An a hour a day |- | Combined cardiovascular, strength, and flexibility training<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/> || * gains in peak oxygen uptake * gains in strength * improvements in body composition * lower blood pressure, and blood sugar * lower cholesterol || An hour a day 3 times per week |- | High intensity interval training [HIIT] and Vigorous exercise<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/><ref>Dr. Mercola. Peak Fitness. (2013). < http://fitness.mercola.com/sites/fitness/archive/2013/10/04/stroke-prevention-vigorous-exercise.aspx> [Accessed: 29/09/14]. </ref> || * reduces stroke risk for men and helps them recover faster || 3 times per week |- |}
Exercise not only lowers the risk factors of having a stroke, it also minimises the disability of someone who has had a stroke and improves their quality of life. Exercise in a stroke survivor prevents complications of prolonged inactivity, decreases risk of recurrent stroke and cardiovascular events, increases aerobic fitness and enhances psychological functioning including concentration, memory and so on<ref name= "Gordan, N.F."/>.
==== Guidelines you should know before getting started ==== If you are on and medications to lower blood pressure, cholesterol or any other health risks it is crucial that you see your doctor before participating in any exercise.
=== Further information/ suggested reading / support groups ===
* Physical activity and exercise recommendations for stroke survivors. [http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/109/16/2031.full Exercise recommendations for stroke survivors ] * Support groups [http://strokefoundation.com.au/afterstroke/get-help/stroke-support-groups/ Stroke support groups- Australia] * Treadmill aerobic exercise for stroke survivors. [http://stroke.ahajournals.org/content/28/2/326.short AHA guidelines] * Lifestyle risk factors for stroke. [http://jech.bmj.com/content/51/2/138.short Effect on stroke risk] * Reduce your stroke risk:[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S39a-BbEwEA Health tip]
=== References ===
<references/>
=== Suitable illustration/ images if appropriate === {{ Exercise as it relates to Disease}}

page.title: Exercise as it relates to Disease/Overcoming sedentary behaviour in combat veterans suffering PTSD through exercise

revision.text:
== Background == === ''Prevalence'' === Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is prevalent in society at 6.4% of the population of Australia <ref>Australian Bureau Of Statistics (2007). National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing. Canberra, Australia.</ref>. When this is compared to those in the military it is higher, believed to be between 7-16% <ref>Richardson, L. K., Frueh, B. C., & Acierno, R. (2010). Prevalence estimates of combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder: critical review. Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry, 44(1), 4-19.</ref>. Sedentary behavior within the military is unlikely to occur due to the values it places on being physically fit and active <ref>Messinger, S. D. (2010). Getting Past the Accident. Medical anthropology quarterly, 24(3), 281-303.</ref>. It is suggested that as rank increases, the amount of time spent sedentary increases posing future health risks <ref>Kennedy-Armbruster, C., Evans, E. M., Sexauer, L., Peterson, J., & Wyatt, W. (2013). Association among functional-movement ability, fatigue, sedentary time, and fitness in 40 years and older active duty military personnel. Military medicine, 178(12), 1358-1364.</ref>. === ''What is PTSD'' === PTSD is a heightened state of stress and anxiety on an individual due to the occurrence of a traumatic event, such as combat or a car accident <ref>Walker, S. (2010). Assessing the mental health consequences of military combat in Iraq and Afghanistan: a literature review. Journal of psychiatric and mental health nursing, 17(9), 790-796.</ref>. === ''What is sedentary behavior'' === Sedentary behavior is a distinctive set of behaviours which are shown by having little physical activity and a low energy expenditure <ref>Chinapaw, M. J. M., Proper, K. I., Brug, J., Van Mechelen, W., & Singh, A. S. (2011). Relationship between young peoples' sedentary behaviour and biomedical health indicators: a systematic review of prospective studies. Obesity Reviews, 12(7), 621-632.</ref>. == Effects on health == Sedentary behavior leads to the following:<ref>Proper, K. I., Singh, A. S., Van Mechelen, W., & Chinapaw, M. J. (2011). Sedentary behaviors and health outcomes among adults: a systematic review of prospective studies. American journal of preventive medicine, 40(2), 174-182.</ref> * Body weight/BMI gain * Being overweight/obese * Waist gain * Type 2 diabetes * Cardiovascular disease risk * Endometrial factors * Mortality due to cardiovascular disease and cancer PTSD often leads to sedentary behavior despite the known benefits of physical activity on both physical and mental self <ref>Rosenbaum, S., Tiedemann, A., Sherrington, C., & van der Ploeg, H. P. (2014). Assessing physical activity in people with posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility and concurrent validity of the International Physical Activity Questionnaire-short form and actigraph accelerometers. BMC research notes, 7(1), 576.</ref>. When someone suffers PTSD they are known to go into isolation and resort from performing physical activity == Current interventions == === ''PTSD''<ref>Imel, Z. E., Laska, K., Jakupcak, M., & Simpson, T. L. (2013). Meta-analysis of dropout in treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder. Journal Of Consulting And Clinical Psychology, 81(3), 394-404</ref> === * Exercise/physical activity * CBT * Exposure therapy * Hypnotherapy * Trauma desensitization * Relapse prevention therapy * Interpersonal therapy * Pharmacotherapy === ''Sedentary behavior'' === Public health stance is to currently increase physical activity with little reference to decreasing the amount of sitting/screen time<ref>Dunstan, D. W., & Owen, N. (2012). New exercise prescription: don't just sit there: stand up and move more, more often: comment on “sitting time and all-cause mortality risk in 222 497 Australian adults”. Archives of internal medicine, 172(6), 500-501.</ref> == Exercise benefits on health == Exercise for PTSD sufferers looks to offer a distraction, taking the mind off of the symptoms, elevate mood levels, decrease anxiety<ref>Cohen, G.E. & Shamus, E. (2009). Depressed, low self-Esteem: What can exercise do for you? The Internet Journal of Allied Health Sciences and Practice, 7(2).</ref> and act as a stress buffer<ref>Tsatsoulis, A. & Fountoulakis, S. (2006). The protective role of exercise on stress system dysregulation and comorbidities. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1083, 196-213.</ref>. Aerobic exercise has been shown to be beneficial<ref>Fetzner, M. G., & Asmundson, G. J. (2014). Aerobic exercise reduces symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Cognitive behaviour therapy, (ahead-of-print), 1-13.</ref> as well as taking part in exercise with groups is shown to have greater effects.
Exercise to physical health helps to overcome many of the problems which are caused by sedentary behaviour. == Exercise recommendations for improving health == Research has shown that there is no difference between high intensity, moderate intensity and low intensity exercise in helping combat veterans suffering PTSD<ref>Stanton, R., & Reaburn, P. (2014). Exercise and the treatment of depression: a review of the exercise program variables. Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport, 17(2), 177-182.</ref> Thus by meeting the physical activity guidelines for Australia would be enough to help. Physical activity guidelines for Australia: * Accumulate 150-300 minutes of moderate intensity physical activity or 75-150 minutes of vigorous physical activity, or an equivalent combination of both each week. * Perform muscle strength training activities on at least 2 days a week. * Be active on most, preferably all days of the week Sedentary behavior guidelines: * Minimize the amount of time spent sitting * Break up long periods of sitting as often as possible As the military has a history of being physically active, by once again becoming physically active will become a saving grace for not only their physical self, but also their mental self as they will return to do something they were once passionate about. It will also improve their health as they will not be sedentary any longer. == Further reading and support == For details of how exercise helps and for healthcare professionals on advice of how to prescribe exercise to PTSD sufferers http://www.unm.edu/~lkravitz/Article%20folder/PTSD.html
For more signs and symptoms of PTSD http://www.combatstress.org.uk/veterans/symptoms-of-trauma/
For help with PTSD from the governments and department of veterans affairs, a dedicated phone app to help http://at-ease.dva.gov.au/veterans/resources/mobile-apps/ptsd-coach/
The current Australian physical activity guidelines http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/health-pubhlth-strateg-phys-act-guidelines == References == {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Radiation Oncology
revision.text: Hi Dr. Muduly. Thank you for your many wonderful contributions to the [[Radiation Oncology]] wikibook. We're grateful for your contributions. Just for your information, you don't need to feel compelled to track every edit you've made on the [[Radiation Oncology/Authors|Authors]] page. The edit counts on that page are deprecated (last updated: July 2010). There are now much easier tools available for keeping track of edits, tools that didn't exist when we first created the wikibook. It's much easier to make use of these tools rather than to keep track of the edit count manually, so we don't worry about it any more. However, if you find it useful to do so, there's no problem. I just didn't want you to feel that you needed to do it. Cheers! — [[User:Brim|Brim]] ([[User talk:Brim|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Brim|contribs]]) 00:56, 22 September 2014 (UTC)

revision.text: {{doc-page-head}} {{TRS-hdrbox|alttitle1=Trainz Template help boilerplate}} ;Purpose and usage This is common boilerplate for multiple See Also template sections referring to other book division's header and footer templates. ;The following is included verbatim in these sections {{typeTaid}} {{typeTdoc}}   The switches above give this Template sufficient scope for most forseen threaded topic groups of topics pages. When they are inappropriate, then these headers present a different mix of switches and messages: * {{tl|AM&C-top}} - Similar role, but for the intermediate topics—intro content and operations and skills building group of page topic types. * {{tl|FUN-top}} - Fundamentals and other basic instruction pages focused mainly on general knowledge or the beginning Trainzer's many learning curves. * {{tl|TRScc-top}} - Content Creation topics pages such as those on advanced techniques * {{tl|ORP-top}} - Used both for {{lc|Trainz references}} (& TOC {{TR}}) — augmented materials sourced from the N3V Wiki, Pages more suitable to the Appendixes (TOC {{TL|Appendixes}} and for topics intersecting AM&C areas for which a category listing (in references) is also desired (so define the AM&C switch parameter).

revision.comment: cat, tweaks
revision.text:
{{doc-page-head}} {{Documentation subpage}} {{FUN-top|both=1|alttitle2=Setting up Trainz properly for yourself|no=1}} ;Purpose —this page is used in pairs with the above type template to style link and, in the case of this template, properly group articles into autocategories if given the same switches as the header template. == Usage == ;Purpose :This template is used with {{Tl|FUN-top}} to set off Trainz Beginner oriented and organized Wiki pages from intermediate topics, content creation, and ''[[:category:Trainz references|Trainz reference classed topics]]'' on the Wiki. * It will also auto-categorize the page to the [[:category:Trainz fundamentals pages]], or with divisions, Introductory pages depending upon page counts to be determined by article counts. The provisional controls ID, IR, IS, IT, and TBKR should be defined the same as any page header and if auto-categorization is needed, the presence of these switches will gate any new subcategories.   :* Given any of the above, currently they act as if defining the parameter 'IT', so the pages are therefore auto-categorized into [[:category:Introductory Trainz]] instead of {{lc|Trainz fundamentals pages}}.   :* Parameter 'ref2' or 'both' also asserts the auto-[[:category: Trainz references]] for use on pages like how to set up Trainz topics, that have a valid life in appendices or references as well.   * It can be given the {{{1}}} default parameter to alter the sort order of the reference page as listed in that category.   '''[[w:Help:pipe trick|pipetrick]] Examples''' on a theoretical page title: "Session editing in Surveyor": #{{FUN-bot||ABC}} ('|ABC' is called a pipe trick) will list the page under the A pages, before any page 'Aeroplane' but after 'Aardvark'.
#{{FUN-bot|editing}} ('|editing' is called a pipe trick) will list the page under the ''''E'''' pages, before any page 'Errors' but after 'Ears'.
* Sorting Difference: {{FUN-bot|ABC}} will list the page under the A pages, before any page 'Aeroplane' but after 'Aardvark'.
'''Contrasting Examples:''' # {{FUN-bot}} on {{TL|Surveyor|H}} will alphabetize the article under ''''H''''... ([[Category:Trainz fundamentals pages|{{PAGENAME}}]])
# {{FUN-bot|inhibit=yes}} on {{TL|Driver}} ''will not categorize the page at all''.
# {{FUN-bot|Engine}} on {{TL|Surveyor}} will alphabetize the article under ''''E''''.
# {{FUN-bot|cat=category-name|Engine}} on {{TL|Session}} will alphabetize the article under '''E''', but not on the [[:category:Trainz fundamentals pages|default category 'Trainz fundamentals pages']] just as a normal [[category:category-name|Engine]] line would do. === See also === {{TRS-header templates}} {{TRS-footer templates}} [[Category:Trainz fundamentals pages|*{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Auto-categorizing templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Both Trainz fundamentals & refs|${{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Trainz formatting templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] ;Trap tester: {{Bad_Call_Param to FUN-bot}} {{typeTdoc}}

revision.text: == SANJIT KHULAL MAGAR ==

page.title: Exercise as it relates to Disease/Aerobic exercise and obstructive sleep apnea

revision.text:
== What is Obstructive Sleep Apnea == Apnea is defined as a ‘cessation of breath’ for at least 10 seconds<ref name="Lawati"/>. Obstructive Sleep Apnea(OSA) also called Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome(OSAS) is the most common form of sleep apnea, affecting 9% of middle aged men and 4% of women.<ref name="Lawati"/> It occurs when there are repeated episodes of complete or partial blockage of the upper airway during sleep. During a sleep apnea episode the diaphragm and chest muscles work harder to open the obstructed airway (that is blocked by the collapse or narrowing of the soft tissue) so air can flow to the lungs. Breathing resumes with a loud gasp, snort or body jerk. These episodes interfere with sleep patterns, can reduce the flow of oxygen to vital organs, and cause irregular heart rhythms.<ref name="name it">Understanding Obstructive Sleep Apnea, 2005-2014. WebMD</ref> [[File:Obstructive sleep apnea event.tif|thumbnail|right|Blocked airway in Obstructive sleep apnea]] == Signs & Symptoms<ref name="name it"/> == *Daytime sleepiness or fatigue *Dry mouth or sore throat upon awakening *Headaches in the morning *Trouble concentrating, forgetfulness, depression, or irritability *Night sweats *Restlessness during sleep *Sexual dysfunction *Snoring *Sudden awakenings with a sensation of gasping or choking *Difficulty getting up in the mornings ==Risk Factors== ===Obesity=== Obesity and indicators for central obesity, such as neck circumference, is one of the main risk factors for developing OSA. Ways in which obesity predisposes to OSA include: *Narrowing of upper airway *Alterations in upper airway function * Reductions in lung volume Studies have shown the a 10% in weight was associated to a 6-fold increase in risk for developing OSA <ref name="Peppard">Peppard T, Young M, (2000)'Longitudinal study of moderate weight change and sleep-disordered breathing'pp. 3015–3021</ref>
===Other Risk Factors=== *Gender - men have twice the risk of developing OSA. This could be due to upper airway fat deposition, larger amounts of soft tissue in the upper airways and hormones are believed to play a role. <ref name="Peppard"/><ref name="Lawati"/> *Ethnicity - African Americans and Asians appear to be at a greater risk *Family history/genetics - The risk of OSA in an individual rises with the increasing number of affected relatives <ref name="Redline"> Redline S, Tishler P & Tosteson P. 'The familial aggregation of obstructive sleep apnea' Am J Respir Crit Care Med, 151 (3 Pt 1) (1995), pp. 682–687</ref> *Nasal obstruction - Increases risk of OSA through the increased negative upper airway pressure produced by inspiratory efforts against a partially occluded nasal airway, turbulence, nasal reflexes, and snoring causing damage/edema to the upper airway soft tissues.<ref name="Mirza"> Mirza N & Lanza D. 'The nasal airway and obstructed breathing during sleep'. 32 (1999), pp. 243–262</ref> *Alcohol - Relaxes the upper airway and may induce OSA on healthy people or chronic snores. And increases the duration and frequency of episodes in those who suffer OSA.<ref name="Scanlan"> Scalan M, Roebuck T & Little P. 'Effect of moderate alcohol upon obstructive sleep apnea'.6 (2000), pp. 909–913</ref> *Smoking - Increase risk could be due to smoking-related airway inflammation and interference in sleep. <ref name="Kashyap"> Kashyap R, Hock L, Bowman T.'Higher prevalence of smoking in patients diagnosed as having obstructive sleep apnea'Sleep Breath, 4 (2001), pp. 167–172</ref> Underlying diseases such as hyperthyriodism and acromegaly and structural abnormalities have also been identified as risk factors.
==Long Term Effects== *Cardiovascular disease <ref name="Java">Javaheri S, Parker TJ, Liming JD, Corbett WS, Nishiyama H, Wexler L & Roselle GA, (1998) 'Sleep apnea in 81 ambulatory male patients with stable heart failure. Types and their prevalences, consequences, and presentations'. PubMed 2;97(21):2154-9.</ref> <ref>Gunnarsson SI, Peppard PE, Korcarz CE, Barnet JH, Aeschlimann SE, Hagen EW, Young T, Hla KM & Stein JH, (2014) 'Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with future subclinical carotid artery disease: thirteen-year follow-up from the wisconsin sleep cohort'. PubMed (10):2338-42. doi: 10.1161/ATVBAHA.114.303965.</ref> *Heart failure <ref>Peppard PE, Young T, Palta M & Skatrud J, (2000) 'Prospective study of the association between sleep-disordered breathing and hypertension.'PubMed 342(19):1378-84. doi: 10.1056/NEJM200005113421901 </ref> *Cardiac arrhythmias <ref> Gami AS1, Pressman G, Caples SM, Kanagala R, Gard JJ, Davison DE, Malouf JF, Ammash NM, Friedman PA & Somers VK, (2004) 'Association of atrial fibrillation and obstructive sleep apnea.'Pubmed 110: 364-367 doi: 10.1161/01.CIR.0000136587.68725.8E. </ref> <ref name="Java"/> *Premature death <ref name="Lawati"> Lawati A, Patel S, Ayas N. (2009) 'Epidemiology, risk factors, and consequences of obstructive sleep apnea and short sleep duration.'51(4):285-93. doi: 10.1016/j.pcad.2008.08.001.</ref> *Development of diabetes <ref name ="Lawati"/>
==Treatment== Common treatments used for OSA are Continuous Positive Airway Pressure(CPAP) and Mandibular advancement devices which pumps steams of air through a mask to hold open the airways. Avoiding alcohol and smoking is recommended and weight loss for those who are overweight<ref> Qaseem A, Holty J, Owens D, Dallas P, Starkey M, Shekelle P.(2013).'Management of Obstructive Sleep Apnea in Adults: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American College of Physicians.'. Annals of Internal Medicine. doi:10.7326/0003-4819-159-7-201310010-00704. PMID 24061345</ref>.
==Effects of aerobic Exercise== Exercise has been shown to be an effective intervention and prevention strategy for OSA as it reduces both the cardiovascular risk factors like blood pressure and other comorbidities <ref name="Roberto"> Silva R, Belli K, Carissmimi A, Fiori C, Faria C & Martinez D. 'Are there benefits of exercise in sleep apnea?' Sleep sci2011;4(2):61-67 </ref> <ref name="wijen">Wijnen H, Boothroyd C, Young MW, Claridge-Chang A. Molecular genetics of timing in intrinsic circadian rhythm sleep disorders. Ann Med. 2002;34:386–393</ref>. Although it has not yet been found that exercise on its own would benefit OSA sufferers, research has shown that exercise should be used as an adjunct to primary treatment with CPAP<ref name="Roberto"/>. As regular aerobic exercise is associated with body weight maintenance, and at higher volumes weight loss, recommendations for increased frequent physical activity accompanying primary treatment from CPAP may be a way to increase energy expenditure and reduce secondary risk factors in OSA <ref name="Roberto"/>. Aerobic exercise training may reduce OSA severity <ref name="kline"> Kline C, Crowley E, Ewing G, Burch J, Blair S, Durstine J, Davis J & Youngstedt S (2013)'Blunted heart rate recovery is improved following exercise training in overweight adults with obstructive sleep apnea.'PubMed 167(4):1610-5. doi: 10.1016/j.ijcard.2012.04.108.</ref>, improve exercise capacity and also improve daytime sleepiness <ref name="linda"> Ueno L, Drager F, Rodrigues A, Rondon M, Braga A, Mathias W, Krieger E, Barretto A, Middlekauff H, Lorenzi-Filho G & Negrão C. (2009) 'Effects of Exercise Training in Patients with Chronic Heart Failure and Sleep Apnea.' 32(5): 637–647.</ref>, and improve quality of life and mood state.
==Recommendations== ===Aerobic exercise <ref> Kline C, Crowley E, Ewing G, Burch J, Blair S, Durstine J, Davis J & Youngstedt S. 'The effect of exercise training on obstructive sleep apnea and sleep quality:a randomized controlled trial.' SLEEP 2011;34(12):1631-1640.</ref>===
{| class="wikitable" |- |Frequency || 3-4 sessions/week |- |Intensity || Moderate- 60% of heart rate reserve (HRR) |- |Type || Walking, Cycling, Swimming |- |Time || 150min/week |}
==Recommended Reading== [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0016269/ Sleep apnea fact sheet]
[http://www.sleep.org.au/information/health-professionals-information/obstructive-sleep-apnoea Autralasian Sleep Association]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
Introduction

What is Reddit?

[[wikipedia|Reddit]] is the self-proclaimed “front page of the internet”. It is an online forum where all content is provided by the users, called redditors. Redditors are characterized by only a username and the content they provide. There is no requirement for the redditor to incorporate any personal identifying information into their content or their username. Due to this, Reddit is largely a community of completely anonymous users that provide web content for each other. Content on Reddit is supplied in the form of hyperlinks to external websites which may display images, text, or any general web content. Users also determine the visibility of content by voting the content either up or down. Content is divided into categories, called subreddits, which are maintained by redditors called moderators. Moderators are charged with guaranteeing that content on their subreddit is relevant and appropriate. Each subreddit typically has rules which content must satisfy in order to stay on the site. These lax restrictions on content coupled with the anonymity of the users makes reddit a unique social space worthy of investigation. How reddit works. (2014, October 13). Retrieved October 13, 2014, from [http://www.redditblog.com/2014/07/how-reddit-works.html]

History

Reddit was started in 2005 by University of Virginia graduates Alex Ohanian and Steve Huffman. Y Combinator, an American seed accelerator, provided the initial funding. Code Nast, a mass media company, acquired Reddit in 2006 which skyrocketed the popularity of the site to 500,000 unique daily visitors on average. In 2008, Reddit became open source and allowed users to create their own subreddits. As of September 2011, the site averaged 1.6 million views a month. A rundown of Reddit’s history and community. (2014, October 11). Retrieved October 19, 2014, from [http://thenextweb.com/socialmedia/2011/10/14/a-rundown-of-reddits-history-and-community-infographic/] Several events allowed for the mass popularity of Reddit. Stephen Colbert launched his "Restoring Truthiness" campaign in response to Glen Beck's "Restoring Honor" rally. Colbert's campaign raised over $600,000 for Donors Choose. A rundown of Reddit’s history and community. (2014, October 11). Retrieved October 19, 2014, from [http://thenextweb.com/socialmedia/2011/10/14/a-rundown-of-reddits-history-and-community-infographic/] In 2012, President Obama hosted a AMA, or "Ask Me Anything", a subreddit dedicated to Q&A sessions between the poster and users. Because so many users tried to join the discussion, the site's web servers crashed. Reddit also participated in protesting the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA) by shutting down their site for a day. The Six Most Important Moments in Reddit History. (2013, October 01). Retrieved October 19, 2014, from [http://techland.time.com/2013/10/01/the-six-most-important-moments-in-reddit-history/]

Participants

* Redditor Content Providers * Redditor Lurkers * Site Moderators * Site Developers * Feeder Site Developers * Law Enforcement # Boston Bombing # r/JailBait * Media Outlets

Subreddits

* Niche Subreddits # What do they tell us? # Would they exist without anonymity?

Cases of Distrust

* Differences between Reddit and IRL in each case * How does anonymity play a role, if any?

Conclusion

References

=Montenegro= * Since 2006 when the country gained independence after the dissolution of Yugoslavia one meter stamp has been reported, a digital stamp used in post offices. * The stamp is inscribed "'''Crna Gora'''" which is the native name in the Montenegrin (and Macedonian) language. ----
[[File: Montenegro stamp type PO1.jpg|left|420px]] [[File: Montenegro stamp type PO1 V.jpg|right|420px]] '''PO1'''. Unidentified (digital). : Self-adhesive label with postal logo (envelope design left of '''Pošta''' / '''Crna Gora''') at upper left. : Large blue letter below the postal logo indicates the type of mail. : Seen so far are "R" for registered mail and "V" for insured mail. : Along the bottom are a 2D barcode and number. : Point-of-sale data in three lines at left of the "R": :::::::::::::::::::: * identification number, date, hour :::::::::::::::::::: * (if "V", "V =" value?), weight in grams :::::::::::::::::::: * value figures ::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 0.00 ----

To use, include the template in a See Also section at page bottom of the documentation. * It has one control switch parameter ''''brief'''', which when defined presents a tighter shorter list of the same links. {{typeTaid}}{{selfTdoc}} {{#if:{{{brief|}}}| * [[Template:R from TRS-alt]] & [[Template:R to TRS-alt]] are more easily typed and remembered (mnemonic names) {{nowrap|of [[Template:R from Trainz alternative name]].}} * [[Template:R to TRS-AM&C]] - Pages relocated to [[:category:Trainz AM&C|Trainz AM&C]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-CC]] - Pages relocated to [[:Category:Trainz Content Creation]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-ref]] - Pages relocated to [[:Category:redirects to Trainz reference pages]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-ver]] - Pages redirecting short colloquial usages for Trainz versions * [[Template:R to TRS-sect]] - for when the redirect is a searchable title, but topic coverage is ''''section title'''' of a page. * [[Template:R from Trainz]] - auto-categorized Trainz Wikibooks redirect terms into the auto-Category: {{lc|redirects from Trainz pages}}. This was the original redirect template, whose use is now depreciated in favor of the most correct from the above list. * [[Template:R from Trainz2]] - Page titles which should eventually be weeded as {{lc|Trainz false starts}}. | * [[Template:R from TRS-alt]] & [[Template:R to TRS-alt]] more easily typed and remembered redirect forms of {{nowrap|[[Template:R from Trainz alternative name]] below.}} * [[Template:R to TRS-AM&C]] - Pages relocated to [[:category:Trainz AM&C|Trainz AM&C]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-CC]] - Pages relocated to [[:Category:Trainz Content Creation]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-ref]] - Pages relocated to [[:Category:redirects to Trainz reference pages]] division pages. * [[Template:R to TRS-ver]] - Pages redirecting short colloquial usages for Trainz versions to formally named release page about the product. * [[Template:R to TRS-sect]] - for when the redirect is a searchable title, but topic coverage is in the section of a page. ;forms somewhat or wholly depreciated * [[Template:R from Trainz alternative name]] - for pages which have been given 'better' (more searchable) names or aliased for easing searching. This is used for page aliased names where both are in the Trainz/subpage_name form, or the page is a general knowledge page that does not neatly fall into a book division such as AM&C, references, etcetera, versus target pages where the text is a subpage of those divisions.   * [[Template:R from Trainz]] - auto-categorized Trainz Wikibooks redirect terms into the auto-Category: {{lc|redirects from Trainz pages}}. This was the original redirect template, whose use is now depreciated in favor of the most correct from the above list.   * [[Template:R from Trainz2]] - This template is used on redirect pages to eventually be deleted, that were ear-marked as split offs into a separate volume, now figured to be a false start... and gained nothing important but more complexity. Maintenance and redirects Auto-category is {{lc|Trainz false starts}}.
 
}}[[category:Trainz redirect templates|$]]

I'm a third year University student from Canberra. I'm studying a Bachelor of Sport, Coaching and Exercise Science.
== Background == I moved to Canberra in 2000 and quickly got involved in the sporting side of the ACT. In year 12 I decided I couldn't see myself working anywhere other than in the sporting world.
== Interests == My biggest interest is sport. My chosen sport is netball and I've been playing for 13 years now. I also enjoy playing touch football occasionally. I passionately follow AFL and my dream job is working with my favourite club. I also model on the side of study and part time work.
== Wikibooks Project ==
One of my assignments this year is to create a wiki page relating to exercise and its effect on a chosen disease.
[[Exercise as a Management Tool for Anxiety]]

page.title: Exercise as it relates to Disease/Exercise as a Management Tool for Anxiety

revision.comment: /* Exercise as a Management Tool */
revision.text:
[[Exercise as it relates to Disease]] == What is Anxiety? ==
It is important to understand that anxiety effects people in different ways. However, central features often include excessive worrying, a negative thought process, distress for unknown reason, and feeling uncomfortable due to the thought that something bad is going to occur. Normal everyday stress is not unusual, it is the body's natural way of reacting to stressful situations and pressure. Anxiety is when the feelings of distress, worry, and feeling uncomfortable or 'on edge' are experienced for prolonged amounts of time.<ref> Understanding and Managing Anxiety, Available From: http://www.psychology.org.au/publications/tip_sheets/anxiety/ </ref>
== Symptoms ==
Symptoms of anxiety can include:
{| class="wikitable" |- | Sweating || Trembling or Shaking || Restlessness |- | Irritability || Racing Heart Rate || Confusion |- | Tightening of Chest || Hot and Cold Flushes || Trouble Sleeping |- | Trouble Concentrating || Upset Stomach or Nausea || <ref> Signs and Symptoms, Available From: http://www.beyondblue.org.au/the-facts/anxiety/signs-and-symptoms </ref> <ref> Understanding and Managing Anxiety, Available From: http://www.psychology.org.au/publications/tip_sheets/anxiety/ </ref> |}
The effects of anxiety can prevent a person from living a normal, happy life if the anxiety is not recognised and managed.
== Who is at risk of suffering from Anxiety? ==
Anxiety can effect anyone of any age and gender. In Australia, anxiety is the most common mental condition, effecting on average, 1 in 4 people. This adds up to over 2 million people in one year. <ref> The Facts, Available From: http://www.beyondblue.org.au/the-facts </ref> Whilst no one can be certain they will never have anxiety, there are a few factors that could make a person more susceptible to suffering from anxiety.
=== Factors that could increase risk of Anxiety===
* Hereditary: Family history of anxiety * Biochemical Factors: An imbalance of emotion regulation and physical reaction chemicals in the brain * Unpleasant Life Experiences: Abuse, bullying, excessive pressure, large work load <ref> Understanding and Managing Anxiety, Available From:http://www.psychology.org.au/publications/tip_sheets/anxiety/ </ref>
== Exercise as a Management Tool ==
A lot of research has gone into finding ways to reduce anxiety symptoms; there are various medications and therapy available.<ref> Medication, Available From: http://www.adaa.org/finding-help/treatment/medication </ref> It is well known that exercise is beneficial for ones physical health, but have you considered it could have a positive influence on your mental health as well. Research has now proven that <big>'''exercise'''</big> can be an effective way of reducing the symptoms of anxiety. "We now have evidence to support the claim that exercise is related to positive mental health as indicated by relief in symptoms of depression and anxiety." (Landers, 1997) Exercise produces endorphins in the brain which act as the body's natural painkillers; they help boost your overall mood. Exercise is said to produce a sense of euphoria and reduce overall stress.<ref> Exercise and Endorphins, Available From: http://www.naturaltherapypages.com.au/article/Exercise_Endorphins </ref>
The results of exercise as a management tool for anxiety can vary for each individual, just as anxiety effects each person differently. Some people find instant relief after exercising, others will experience gradual relief, some people will have temporary relief and others will have long term management of their anxiety.
=== What type of exercise is best? ===
Research suggests that aerobic exercise is more beneficial in reducing anxiety.<ref> Exercise and Endorphins, Available From: http://www.naturaltherapypages.com.au/article/Exercise_Endorphins </ref> This includes activities such as jogging, cycling and swimming. Exercise as a management tool for anxiety is said to also be more effective when exercise is regular over a few weeks opposed to a one off occurrence. <ref> The influence of Exercise on Mental Health, Available From: http://www.portalsaudebrasil.com/artigospsb/psico046.pdf </ref> However, some individuals may still benefit from strength exercises as well as more relaxing exercises such as yoga. Some people may just need a brisk walk around the block to de-stress.
== Recommendations ==
Based on the information above, aerobic exercise as a management tool for anxiety would be the best place to start. This includes exercises such as: * Running * Jogging * Walking * Cycling * Swimming These types of exercise all increase heart rate and release feel good endorphins. Other types of anxiety management exercises include: Strength training, Yoga and Pilaties. Each person is different and will react differently to various exercises. Don't hesitate to ''contact a professional'' and ask them to discuss exercise options with you.
== Further Readings and Information ==
* For additional information and help: http://www.beyondblue.org.au/the-facts/anxiety * For additional information on aerobic exercises: http://www.bupa.com.au/health-and-wellness/health-information/az-health-information/types-of-aerobic-exercise
== References ==
* Beyondblue.org.au,. (2014). beyondblue. Retrieved 23 September 2014, from http://www.beyondblue.org.au/the-facts * Beyondblue.org.au,. (2014). beyondblue. Retrieved 23 September 2014, from http://www.beyondblue.org.au/the-facts/anxiety/signs-and-symptoms * Psychology.org.au,. (2014). Australian Psychological Society : Understanding and managing anxiety. Retrieved 23 September 2014, from http://www.psychology.org.au/publications/tip_sheets/anxiety/ * Adaa.org,. (2014). Exercise for Stress and Anxiety | Anxiety and Depression Association of America, ADAA. Retrieved 23 September 2014, from http://www.adaa.org/living-with-anxiety/managing-anxiety/exercise-stress-and-anxiety * Australia, N. (2014). article: Exercise and Endorphins. Natural Therapy Pages. Retrieved 23 September 2014, from http://www.naturaltherapypages.com.au/article/Exercise_Endorphins. * Landers, D. (1997). The influence of exercise on mental health (1st ed.). Washington, DC: President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. * Adaa.org,. (2014). Medication | Anxiety and Depression Association of America, ADAA. Retrieved 24 September 2014, from http://www.adaa.org/finding-help/treatment/medication * Mayoclinic.org,. (2014). Depression and anxiety: Exercise eases symptoms - Mayo Clinic. Retrieved 24 September 2014, from http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/depression/in-depth/depression-and-exercise/art-20046495 {{BookCat}}
